BC-PHOTO-UPDATE-NYT 
   ATTENTION EDITORS: The following photos are part of tonight's
New York Times Photo Package, moving Wednesday, 05/31/00. Photo
clients will automatically receive these photos via AP's
PhotoExpress or may download them from either the Wieck Photo
Database in Dallas at 972-392-0888 or from NYTPhotos on Newscom at
305-448-8411. Non-clients can make individual purchases by calling
(888) 603-1036 or 212-556-4204.

   (NYT37) INDIANAPOLIS -- May 31, 2000 -- BKN-KNICKS-PACERS-2 --
Latrell Sprewell of the New York Knicks is surrounded by Indiana
Pacers during the first half of Game 5 of the NBA's Eastern
Conference Finals at Conseco Fieldhouse on Wednesday night. The
series was tied at 2-2. (Barton Silverman/The New York Times)

   (NYT36) INDIANAPOLIS -- May 31, 2000 -- BKN-KNICKS-PACERS-1 --
Reggie Miller of the Indiana Pacers trying to stop Allan Houston of
the New York Knicks during the first half of Game 5 of the NBA's
Eastern Conference Finals at Conseco Fieldhouse on Wednesday night.
The series was tied at 2-2. (Barton Silverman/The New York Times)

   (NYT35) NEW DELHI, India -- May 31, 2000 -- INDIA-JUSTICE-3 --
In India's courts, some 25 million cases are pending. Notaries
worked outside a New Delhi court. Court clerks wield immense power.
For each service, a bribe of 10 rupees - about 25 cents - is an
expected courtesy. (Barry Bearak/The New York Times)

   (NYT34) MORADABAD, India -- May 31, 2000 -- INDIA-JUSTICE-2 --
In India's courts, some 25 million cases are pending, a
breath-taking pileup of the untried accused and unsatisfied
aggrieved. The Wazid family of Moradabad stood by the wall that is
at the root of the lawsuit that began 39 years and several hundred
court dates ago. (Barry Bearak/The New York Times)

   (NYT33) UNDATED -- May 31, 2000 -- SCI-UNWRAPPING-CANDY -- A
team of physicists has demonstrated what plenof concertgoers
distracted by the crinkling and crackling of candy wrappers already
know: The noise is inevitable no matter how much care is taken in
freeing the candy from its wrapper. (James Estrin/The New York
Times)

   (NYT32) NEW YORK -- May 31, 2000 -- ISRAEL-U.N.-2 -- Until last
week, Israel, a member of the United Nations since 1949, had been
barred from the Asian caucus, which includes the Middle East, since
the 1960s. ``We understand that our membership is on a temporary
basis, and we accept that,'' said Yehuda Lancry, the Israeli
ambassador to the U.N., adding that Israeli still had hopes of
entering the Asian bloc when peace efforts succeed in the Middle
East. (Chester Higgins Jr./The New York Times)

   (NYT31) BEIJING -- May 31, 2000 -- CHINA-PROPAGANDA -- In a
classic propaganda campaign, the ``brilliant thesis'' of Jiang
Zemin - the Communist Party chief and president - has been pouring
from virtually every media outlet. Some leafed through the 74-page
booklet, called ``A Great Program for Comprehensively Strengthening
Party-Building'' (which included Jiang's recent speeches), at the
Xinhua Bookstore in Beijing on Wednesday. (Erik Eckholm/The New
York Times)

   (NYT30) WATKINS GLEN, N.Y. -- May 31, 2000 -- NY-LAZIO -- Rep.
Rich A. Lazio, holding microphone, addressed supporters Wednesday
in Watkins Glen with his wife, Patricia, on a stool. Lazio sought
to build momentum in his fledgling campaign for the Senate, riding
his newly christened ``Mainstream Express'' bus across upstate New
York as he greeted supporters and refined his stump speech. (Ruth
Fremson/The New York Times)

   (NYT29) NAGO, Japan -- May 31, 2000 -- OKINAWA-RAPE -- Kijun
Kishimoto, an 84-year-old retired school principal who grew up in
Katsuyama, Okinawa, said he was told that villagers killed three
marines who had been raping their women shortly before the end of
World War II. ``People were very afraid that if the Americans found
out what happened there would be retaliation, so they decided to
keep it a secret to protect those involved,'' he said. (Calvin
Sims/The New York Times)

   (NYT28) ELKMONT, Tenn. -- May 31, 2000 -- SMOKIES-BEARS-2-COX --
The Little River Trail has always been one of the most popular in
the Great Smoky Mountains National Park. But, after a black bear
mauled a Tennessee school teacher on the trail May 21, park rangers
have had to post warning notices. The fatality is the first from a
bear attack in the park's 66-year history. Jay Kelley, left, and
his son, Shane, chose to hike the trail but kept an eye out for
bear. (Marlon Manuel/The Atlanta Journal Constitution)

   (NYT27) ELKMONT, Tenn. -- May 31, 2000 -- SMOKIES-BEARS-1-COX --
The Little River Trail has always been one of the most popular in
the Great Smoky Mountains National Park. But, after a black bear
mauled a Tennessee school teacher on the trail May 21, park rangers
have had to post warning notices. The fatality is the first from a
bear attack in the park's 66-year history. (Marlon Manuel/The
Atlanta Journal Constitution)

   (NYT26) UNDATED -- May 31, 2000 -- HOME-IMPROVEMENT-B&W -- One
way to refinish a kitchen countertop where the plastic laminate is
worn is to resurface it with ceramic tile. First, check the
condition of the laminate carefully. The surface must be flat,
relatively smooth and firmly bonded to the counter. Once you have
determined that the laminate bond is secure, you can pick out the
tiles you want for the counter. (Edward R. Lipinski/The New York
Times) LITE

   (NYT25) NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J. -- May 31, 2000 -- PSORIASIS-BIOTECH
-- The biotechnology industry is taking aim at psoriasis, a chronic
disease that affects an estimated 7 million Americans and, in its
more serious forms, is far more physically and psychologically
devastating than the mere cosmetic disease it is often thought to
be. ``There's been a renaissance in drug development,'' said Dr.
Alice B. Gottlieb, director of clinical research at the Robert Wood
Johnson Medical School. (Nancy Wegard/The New York Times) LITE

   (NYT24) JURDEIKH, Israel -- May 31, 2000 -- ISRAEL-U.N. -- An
Israeli soldier helps to deliver a note from an Israeli Arab to
their relative on the Lebanese side of the border, Wednesday. The
United Nations' Middle East envoy said Wednesday that Syria had
fully accepted a U.N. report that concluded an Israeli withdrawal
from Lebanon did not require handing over the Shebaa Farms area.
(Rina Castelnuovo/The New York Times) LITE

   (NYT23) WASHINGTON -- May 31, 2000 -- GORE-MENTAL-HEALTH -- In
an unusually personal campaign appearance with his wife Tipper,
Vice President Al Gore proposed Wednesday requiring insurance
companies to cover mental health services for children under the
same co-payments and deductibles used for other health benefits.
Gore during an interview with the New York Times, Wednesday. (Paul
Hosefros/The New York Times)

   (NYT22) UNDATED -- May 31, 2000 -- SALAD-GREENS-COX -- June
meets the need for green vegetables in its proliferation of salad
greens. And this year, after a cool May, the crop is bountiful.
Japanese cabbage, left, and salad burnet. (Jim Witmer/The Cox News
Service)

   (NYT21) NEW YORK -- May 31, 2000 -- NY-WENDYS-SUSPECT -- Even as
police and prosecutors amass what they depict as an overwhelming
volume of evidence against John Taylor and his alleged accomplice
in the murders of employees at a Wendys restaurant last week, law
enforcement officials acknowledge they have gained little insight
into what motivated the cold viciousness of the murders. Taylor is
taken from the local police station after his arrest. (William C.
Lopez/The New York Times)

   (NYT20) WASHINGTON -- May 31, 2000 -- PHONE-CHARGES -- The
Federal Communications Commission (FCC) and most of the nation's
leading telephone companies announced Wednesday a sweeping
reshuffling of the telephone rates that should reduce costs for all
businesses and consumers. William Kennard, chairman of the FCC,
announces the changes in phone rates during a news conference.
(Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)

   (NYT19) WALES, Mass. -- May 31, 2000 -- CIR-VIRTUAL-VIETNAM-WALL
-- Ron McClain, wounded in the Mekong Delta, has used the The
Virtual Wall Web site to find men he served with in the war. The
site includes information about the real Vietnam memorial wall and
a traveling replica, an image gallery and a link to the home page
of the Vietnam Veterans Memorial Fund. But the main feature is the
virtual wall itself: Each of the 140 granite panels of the real
wall can be viewed. (George Ruhe/The New York Times)

   (NYT18) NEW YORK -- May 31, 2000 -- RAUSCHENBERG-PAINTING-2 --
Mathilde Krim, right foreground, supervising ``her'' panels in a
new work by Rauschenberg called ``Synapsis Shuffle.'' The panels
are meant to be assembled by a different group of people every time
they are shown, so the work will never be seen the same way twice.
(Sara Krulwich/The New York Times)

   (NYT17) NEW YORK -- May 31, 2000 -- RAUSCHENBERG-PAINTING-1 --
Merce Cunningham, left, Renee Fleming and Robert Rauschenberg
during the creation of ``Synapsis Shuffle.'' Like a deck of cards,
the panels that make up ``Synapsis Shuffle,'' Rauschenberg's latest
work, are meant to be assembled by a different group of people
every time they are shown, so the work will never be seen the same
way twice. (Sara Krulwich/The New York Times)

   (NYT16) MORADABAD, India -- May 31, 2000 -- INDIA-JUSTICE -- If,
as the adage goes, justice delayed is justice denied, then India's
courts can be said to customarily live in a state of denial. Some
25 million cases are pending, a breath-taking pileup of the untried
accused and unsatisfied aggrieved. By one expert's calculation, if
no new actions are filed, 324 years would be needed to clear the
dockets. Lawyers, or advocates as they are known, in stalls near
the local courthouse. (Barry Bearak/The New York Times) LITE

   (NYT15) WASHINGTON -- May 31, 2000 -- BOLSHOI-U.S.-2 -- Capulets
and Montagues clash in ``Romeo and Juliet,'' performed by the
Bolshoi Ballet in Washington. The return of the Bolshoi from Moscow
for its first United States tour in 10 years fills a gap for
American audiences that has been sorely felt. (Susana Raab/The New
York Times)

   (NYT14) WASHINGTON -- May 31, 2000 -- BOLSHOI-U.S.-1 -- The
return of the Bolshoi Ballet from Moscow for its first United
States tour in 10 years fills a gap for American audiences that has
been sorely felt. Andrei Uvarov and Nina Ananiashvili as Romeo and
Juliet during a rehearsal on Tuesday. (Susana Raab/The New York
Times) LITE

   (NYT13) NEW YORK -- May 31, 2000 -- NY-COWS-COPYRIGHT -- An
artist painting a cow for New York's cow parade, in which some 500
fiberglass cows will be on display in all five boroughs in June.
Sponsors pay $7,500 a head, of which $2,000 goes to the artist.
(Ruby Washington/The New York Times)

   (NYT12) HARTFORD, Conn. -- May 31, 2000 -- AUSTIN-HOUSE-3 --
Arthur Everett Austin Jr.'s house will greet Hartford society again
when the Atheneum, which owns the Austin house and has restored it,
will unveil it to trustees next Thursday. The interior has 56
custom colors, mixed by Austin. The living room's blue-green was
taken from its 18th-century murals. The carved entrance is an
armoire front and doors. The music room beyond has a suite of
chinoiserie panels. The canape sofa is 18th-century Neapolitan.
(Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times)

   (NYT11) WASHINGTON -- May 31, 2000 -- SPELLING-BEE-COX -- Chip
Norris, 13, a seventh grade student from Chipley, Fla., listens to
other spellers as he awaits his turn to compete at the National
Spelling Bee, Wednesday. Norris was among 248 contestants in the
bee, many of them fidgeting and twisting in their chairs upon
hearing a dreaded bell that signals mistakes. (Rick McKay/Cox News
Service)

   (NYT10) UNDATED -- May 31, 2000 -- KOREA-MASSACRE-DAILY-B&W --
Edward Daily had all the trappings of an American war hero. But his
presence at No Gun Ri, in fact, most of Daily's military record,
appears to be invented or imagined. A copy of a letter Daily's
friends said he showed them concerning his Silver Star award and
promotion. But Army records show no sign that either was conferred.
(The New York Times)

   (NYT9) HARTFORD, Conn. -- May 31, 2000 -- AUSTIN-HOUSE-2 --
After 20 months and half a million dollars of cosmetic labor, the
``pasteboard palace,'' as local grandees dubbed Arthur Everett
Austin Jr.'s house, will greet Hartford society again. The
Atheneum, which now owns the Austin house and has restored it, will
unveil it to trustees next Thursday. A dining room in the restored
house. (Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times)

   (NYT8) HARTFORD, Conn. -- May 31, 2000 -- AUSTIN-HOUSE-1 --
After 20 months and half a million dollars of cosmetic labor, the
``pasteboard palace,'' as local grandees dubbed Arthur Everett
Austin Jr.'s house, will greet Hartford society again. The
Atheneum, which now owns the Austin house and has restored it, will
unveil it to trustees next Thursday. (Fred R. Conrad/The New York
Times)

   (NYT7) NEW YORK -- May 31, 2000 -- HARLEM-HOUSE-3 -- Michael
Adams, a Harlem private-tour impresario, has decorated his Harlem
home with various assortments of lost-and-found objects. His
apartment opens onto a garden ruin where an almost life-size
plaster lamp base reigns as resident muse. (Fred R. Conrad/The New
York Times)

   (NYT6) NEW YORK -- May 31, 2000 -- HARLEM-HOUSE-2 -- Michael
Adams, a Harlem private-tour impresario, has decorated his Harlem
home with various assortments of lost-and-found objects. A Chicago
artist gave a primitive portrait to Adams when he moved in to his
apartment; it hangs over a guitar which Adams found when moving in.
(Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times)

   (NYT5) NEW YORK -- May 31, 2000 -- HARLEM-HOUSE-1 -- Michael
Adams, a Harlem private-tour impresario, has decorated his Harlem
home with various assortments of lost-and-found objects. At the end
of the year, Monacelli Press is bringing out his architectural
compendium on Harlem titled, ``Harlem: Lost and Found: 1765-1915.''
(Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times)

   (NYT4) NEW BRUNSWICK-- May 31, 2000 -- ACTIVIST-PROFILE --
Charlotte Bunch is an earnest woman with a mission: to build a
worldwide network of feminists who will press their local
governments to end violence against women, be it genital mutilation
in Africa, bride burning in India, honor killing in the Middle East
or rape on the battlefields of Bosnia. Bunch, director of the
Center for Women's Global Leadership at Rutgers University, during
an interview last week. (Marilynn K. Yee/The New York Times)

   (NYT3) UNDATED -- May 31, 2000 -- ACTOR-2 -- Walking home last
Monday, Randolph Walker, an actor, was fatally struck by a double
decker tour bus setting off a wave of outrage against its operator,
the problem-ridden New York Apple Tours. New York's acting rank and
file, who live the rare highs and relentless lows of this city's
performing profession, had lost one of its own. Walker in an
advertisement for a Kodak camera in 1991. (The New York Times)

   (NYT2) UNDATED -- May 31, 2000 -- ACTOR-1-B&W -- Walking home
last Monday, Randolph Walker, an actor, was fatally struck by a
double decker tour bus setting off a wave of outrage against its
operator, the problem-ridden New York Apple Tours. New York's
acting rank and file, who live the rare highs and relentless lows
of this city's performing profession, had lost one of its own. A
portrait of Walker, left, an in character as Sir Edward Ramsay in
the 1976 revival of ``The King and I.'' (The New York Times)

   (NYT1) NEW YORK -- May 31, 2000 -- CIR-BROOKLYN-BRIDGE -- Since
it was opened in 1883, the Brooklyn Bridge has become a national
icon. Several sites on the Internet provide information about the
myths and history of the famous span and about its designer, John
A. Roebling. (Suzanne DeChillo/The New York Times)

   The New York Times News Service
